avalancheActivity.highlights: Further increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall becomes more intense.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase from midday. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience and great restraint.

Warming to above approximately 1400 m. The rain will give rise from midday to rapid moistening of the snowpack on steep slopes below approximately 1500 m. At low altitude and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist snow slides and avalanches are possible as a consequence of the rain. On very steep slopes natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Over a wide area 40 to 70 cm of snow fell on Monday above approximately 1100 m. 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall today.

Warming to above approximately 1400 m. These weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack in particular at low altitude.

In the course of the day mostly small wind slabs will form at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

avalancheActivity.highlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes moderate wind from southeasterly directions, wind slabs will form in the course of the day at intermediate and high altitudes. On steep slopes the likelihood of avalanches is quite high. Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches in many places, including medium-sized ones. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

Warming: The rain will give rise from midday to significant moistening of the snowpack below approximately 1500 m. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are not ruled out.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow fell on Monday above approximately 1500 m. 25 to 30 cm of snow will fall today. In the course of the day sometimes deep wind slabs will form at intermediate and high altitudes.

The sleet will give rise from midday to rapid moistening of the snowpack below approximately 1500 m.

avalancheActivity.highlights: The fresh snow and the deep wind slabs can be released easily.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on wind-loaded slopes the wind slabs are larger.

On steep west, north and east facing slopes the avalanches can be triggered in the old snow and reach large size in isolated cases. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack are a clear indication. At low and intermediate altitudes the avalanches can release the moist old snow as well.

The sleet will give rise from midday to rapid moistening of the snowpack below approximately 1500 m. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase in particular on steep slopes at low altitude.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Over a wide area 25 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Monday above approximately 1500 m. In some regions 30 cm of snow will fall today.

As a consequence of the sometimes moderate wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally as the day progresses. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on wind-loaded slopes the wind slabs are larger.

The sleet will give rise from midday to rapid moistening of the snowpack below approximately 1500 m.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Locally increased avalanche danger in the upper reaches of valleys bordering Valle d'Aosta.
avalancheActivity.comment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on northwest to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2200 m.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized but can be released in isolated cases even by a single winter sport participant.

The numerous rocks hidden by the recent snow are the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The new snow and wind slabs of last week are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

Below approximately 2000 m from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
